item.title: snowflake and other data warehouses charge massive margins. would love to see a crypto-powered alternative chip away at those margins and create a more competitive + liquid marketplace
item.dc:creator: @notnotstorm

item.title:
RT by @notnotstorm: Next-slot real-time proving is coming in 2025.
This year I expect multiple zkVM vendors to prove mainnet EVM blocks on GPUs in less than 12 seconds, at <$0.10 per block. Performance numbers will get crazier with SNARK ASICS. Follow the journey on @eth_proofs.
No L1 is poised to benefit from real-time zkVMs nearly as much as Ethereum. zk is how Ethereum scales sustainably, with full validation for stakers and wallets accessible to phones and watches. Real-time zk is the endgame :)
item.dc:creator: @drakefjustin
item.description:
Next-slot real-time proving is coming in 2025.

This year I expect multiple zkVM vendors to prove mainnet EVM blocks on GPUs in less than 12 seconds, at <$0.10 per block. Performance numbers will get crazier with SNARK ASICS. Follow the journey on @eth_proofs.

No L1 is poised to benefit from real-time zkVMs nearly as much as Ethereum. zk is how Ethereum scales sustainably, with full validation for stakers and wallets accessible to phones and watches. Real-time zk is the endgame :)

item.title:
R to @notnotstorm: the @ethPandaOps team probably has the most experience running lots of clients at once
how hard do you think it would be to build a robust metaclient orchestrator that lets anyone run all the clients they want on a single machine with low maintenance burden for node operators? @BarnabasBusa @mattevansnz @parithosh_j @_pk910_ @samcmAU @Savid @skylenet

item.title:
on eth/acc: waiting for only M-of-N node clients to launch new hardforks (with M<N) would be a lot more practical if there were a ‚Äúmetaclient‚Äù tool like @peter_szilagyi used to talk about
a lot of new patterns get unlocked if there is a system that makes it effortless to run two or more clients on a single machine. this includes ‚Äúleave no validator behind‚Äù, even when one of the node implementations isnt ready for the fork
item.dc:creator: @notnotstorm

item.title: it's exciting that everyone hates this roadmap
item.dc:creator: @notnotstorm
item.description:
it's exciting that everyone hates this roadmap

nitter.freedit.eu/notnotstorm/status/1881041568263790828#m

item.title:
RT by @notnotstorm: Some points on this:
1. The current process of upgrading Ethereum IS BROKEN. Builders need long-term commitments to capacity, otherwise they cannot build on Ethereum. They need to know what the plan is in 5 years. So I hope that we can finally agree to timelines in the core dev process.
2. We nonsensically claim that L1 cannot be scaled and L2s are the only way. This is a complete ivory tower perspective -- Vitalik already posted this 3 years ago, and with DAS and zkEVMs the ingredients are now ready: https://vitalik.eth.limo/general/2021/12/06/endgame.html There are limits to this, yes, but scaling it 100-1000x in a few years is completely possible. This achieves many things that based/native/etc. rollups don't. I think actually doing this and stopping to find excuses for not doing it is essential for Ethereum winning.
3. Not everything can be on Ethereum L1, whether the actual limit is 1k or 100k tps or maybe even 1M tps. For this it is still great to add lots of data availability and create a great Ethereum security zones for rollups, who are Ethereum allies and can use Ether and all other Ethereum assets trustlessly. But we need to do it at a scale that actually matters. We need to get to our current target of one Megabyte per second in 1-2 years rather than 5, and then KEEP GOING. I am currently doing research on maximally decentralizing the networking DAS/Data Availability Sampling, but until that's done, adding Data Availability Provider nodes with higher requirements is a good solution that has the same security assumptions as optimistic rollups (one honest node). Other Data Availability protocols are currently building for GB/s! Ethereum does not have to match this, but being at 1/1000ths is not good enough. Some projects are openly stating already that they will never use Ethereum DA (and openly advertising with Vitalik's support! The irony). Being ok with that and still claiming that they are somehow "Ethereum aligned" is thoroughly un-ambitious.
item.dc:creator: @dankrad
item.description:
Some points on this:

1. The current process of upgrading Ethereum IS BROKEN. Builders need long-term commitments to capacity, otherwise they cannot build on Ethereum. They need to know what the plan is in 5 years.
So I hope that we can finally agree to timelines in the core dev process.

2. We nonsensically claim that L1 cannot be scaled and L2s are the only way.
This is a complete ivory tower perspective -- Vitalik already posted this 3 years ago, and with DAS and zkEVMs the ingredients are now ready: vitalik.eth.limo/general/202‚Ä¶
There are limits to this, yes, but scaling it 100-1000x in a few years is completely possible.
This achieves many things that based/native/etc. rollups don't.
I think actually doing this and stopping to find excuses for not doing it is essential for Ethereum winning.

3. Not everything can be on Ethereum L1, whether the actual limit is 1k or 100k tps or maybe even 1M tps. For this it is still great to add lots of data availability and create a great Ethereum security zones for rollups, who are Ethereum allies and can use Ether and all other Ethereum assets trustlessly.
But we need to do it at a scale that actually matters. We need to get to our current target of one Megabyte per second in 1-2 years rather than 5, and then KEEP GOING. I am currently doing research on maximally decentralizing the networking DAS/Data Availability Sampling, but until that's done, adding Data Availability Provider nodes with higher requirements is a good solution that has the same security assumptions as optimistic rollups (one honest node).
Other Data Availability protocols are currently building for GB/s! Ethereum does not have to match this, but being at 1/1000ths is not good enough.
Some projects are openly stating already that they will never use Ethereum DA (and openly advertising with Vitalik's support! The irony). Being ok with that and still claiming that they are somehow "Ethereum aligned" is thoroughly un-ambitious.

nitter.freedit.eu/dankrad/status/1881387224350052528#m

item.title:
RT by @notnotstorm: So finally we are talking about how the current plan is just way too unambitious.
If Ethereum wants to win, we need to be ambitious.
item.dc:creator: @dankrad
item.description:
So finally we are talking about how the current plan is just way too unambitious.

If Ethereum wants to win, we need to be ambitious.

this is my understanding/prediction for the ethereum scaling roadmap
continual improvements to hardware, software, and protocols will support gas+blob increases without compromising network health

item.title:
crypto data becomes good if and only if it's prioritized by ecosystem + leadership
crypto data has always been trust-but-verify. but instead of telling ppl to deprioritize data, we should tell ecosystems + leaders to step up and make good data a priority. data = tablestakes
item.dc:creator: @notnotstorm
item.description:

item.title:
cache-aware storage pricing would be a nice boost for scaling ethereum L1
if node clients cached 100K storage slots, that could make >50% of all storage reads virtually free (and it would require only 10's of MB's of memory)
item.dc:creator: @notnotstorm
item.description:
